instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Power cycling <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL> & Clock
threads.message:
Hi Guys,

I'm back! :) but a little out of practice with the board repair thought process.


This board, originally it came in with a blown ground trace on <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> which I repaired. The repair ended up being abandoned at it found a new home as my shop computer.

About two weeks ago I rebooted and it stuck on a black screen with a backlight, about 15 minutes later it finally chimed. A day later it decided to not resume from sleep and has pretty much never turned on again. Originally the CPU was getting warm and the fan would spin up, USB mouse had a red light. So it seemed alive, just never completed a post.

Now it's totally dead with a cycling <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL> @ <RESISTOR>R1460</RESISTOR>.
All the all measurements around <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> are bouncing too, but I think this might be a symptom of the real issue.

Any help appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Power cycling <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL> & Clock
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Power cycling <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL> & Clock
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Power cycling <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL> & Clock
threads.message:
Get's a green / orange light as expected.

PPBus = 12.59.
<SIGNAL>P3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.33
PPVRTC = 3.33

I felt heat around L7095 the once time I plugged it in, but can't reproduce it again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Power cycling <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL> & Clock
threads.message:
L7095::2 in diode mode gives me 0.095.
I think that might be a little low.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Power cycling <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL> & Clock
threads.message:
This ones to the junk pile.

I just smoked the board by misreading the schematic. :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Power cycling <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL> & Clock
threads.message:
Actually, which stencil would I use for the SMC on this board?

I blew the SMC when I mixed up <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and PP3v3, might as well learn how to replace the SMC on this once since I have several donors.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Power cycling <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL> & Clock
threads.message:
If PPBUS got to the 3V42 line then there is a lot more fried than just the SMC. You will need to replace every single semiconductor on the 3V42 rail, I guess about 10 parts total, including Hall sensor for lid. 
Use search function for SMC stencil, has been linked to multiple times in the past.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Power cycling <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL> & Clock
threads.message:
Yeh, that's why I threw it in the parts bin originally.

But figured I may as well practice SMC replacements on it since I have a bunch of boards the same and it's the one of the only repairs I've never done.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Power cycling <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL> & Clock
threads.message: The thing here is, you are going to replace all these parts and then end up with a board that is still dead and will power cycle. Huge time waster board, unless you have nothing else to do just trash it.
